intro: Parastemon spicatus, commonly known as the spiculate parastemon, is a flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Boraginaceae family, characterized by its hairy stems and blue or purple flowers. The plant typically grows as a low, sprawling shrub with small, lance-shaped leaves. It produces clusters of tubular flowers that attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Parastemon spicatus is adapted to drought conditions and is often found in rocky soils and open habitats.
